title: Bramha
description:
# Bramha's path to market: an evidence-based GTM strategy for Swiss SMEs

**Bramha should launch as a competitive intelligence platform for Swiss medtech and MEM (machinery/electrical/metals) SMEs, bundling AI-powered intelligence with implementation workshops — a combination no competitor currently offers.** The timing is exceptional: TEPA entered into force on October 1, 2025, giving Swiss firms tariff advantages over EU competitors in India; US tariffs sit at 15% after a volatile year; the Swiss franc is at decade highs; and a regulatory tsunami (CBAM, CSRD, AI Act) is hitting export-dependent SMEs with no affordable monitoring tools available. These ~2,500 addressable SMEs across medtech and MEM face compounding pressures that create urgent, measurable demand for competitive intelligence — and they are actively spending on market diversification, digital tools, and compliance.

---

## TEPA gives Swiss SMEs a rare first-mover window into India

The India-EFTA Trade and Economic Partnership Agreement, signed March 10, 2024 and **entered into force October 1, 2025**, is the most significant Swiss trade development in a decade. After 16 years and 21 rounds of negotiations, it covers **84.6% of Swiss exports** with full tariff elimination over phase-in periods of up to 10 years. The critical strategic fact: **the EU does not have an FTA with India**. Swiss companies now hold a cost advantage over German, French, and Italian competitors in a market of 1.4 billion consumers.

The tariff reductions are substantial. Swiss watches face a phaseout of India's 22% duty over 7 years. Machinery tariffs of 7.5–10% move toward elimination. Medical devices receive preferential treatment. Processed foods like chocolate gain duty-free access after a 10-year transition. SECO estimates additional Swiss exports worth **~CHF 170 million per year** from tariff abolition alone. The agreement also includes a $100 billion EFTA investment commitment over 15 years, with enforcement teeth — India can suspend tariff concessions if investments don't materialize.

This directly creates CI demand. Swiss SMEs entering India's complex market need intelligence on Indian competitors, regulatory requirements (BIS certification, CAROTAR 2020 origin rules), regional market variations, distributor identification, and pricing strategies. PwC Switzerland explicitly warns companies to "identify regulatory fit-gaps early, plan inspection schedules and factory audits, and adjust products to Indian standards." The India-EFTA Desk, operational since February 2025, prioritizes renewable energy, life sciences, engineering, and digital transformation — but provides facilitation, not intelligence.

Government support infrastructure exists but is human-driven and not scalable. Switzerland Global Enterprise (S-GE) supported **6,642 companies across 142 markets** in 2024. The Swiss Business Hub India in Mumbai offers market information, distributor searches, and fact-finding missions. Swissnex India provides innovation market intelligence. However, **48% of Swiss SMEs are not even considering new target markets** according to S-GE surveys — suggesting the intelligence and confidence gap is real. An automated, continuously updated CI platform fills the space between S-GE's free but basic GoGlobal Cockpit and expensive Big 4 consulting engagements.

---

## The perfect storm hitting Swiss SMEs in 2025–2026

Swiss SMEs face the most complex operating environment in decades, with multiple simultaneous pressures creating urgent demand for intelligence tools. Recent survey data paints a stark picture.

**Geopolitical uncertainty dominates.** The 2025 Swiss SME Study (swiss.export/Kearney) found **70% of SMEs cite foreign policy as their main economic risk** — up 29 percentage points from 2024. Only 52% assess their future positively, down from 68% the prior year. The Deloitte CFO Survey recorded an **84-point collapse in economic sentiment** after the April 2025 tariff announcement. US tariffs on Swiss goods hit 39% in August 2025 before being negotiated down to 15% in November — a rollercoaster that destroyed planning confidence. Watch exports to the US plummeted **56% in September 2025** year-over-year. Swissmem reported 38% of tech industry companies planning dismissals.

**The Swiss franc compounds the pain.** EUR/CHF hit an all-time low of **0.918 in November 2025**, and USD/CHF sits around 0.776 — the strongest level in over a decade. Swissmem identifies fair value at EUR/CHF 0.98, meaning the franc is approximately 6% overvalued against the euro. Combined with tariffs, this creates a "perfect storm" for export-dependent manufacturers. The SNB has cut its policy rate to 0.0% with limited room for further action.

**Germany's industrial recession cascades into Switzerland.** MEM industry sales fell through nine consecutive quarters of year-over-year decline. SME sales within the MEM sector dropped **9% in the first three quarters of 2025**. Q2 2025 order intake collapsed 13.4% quarter-on-quarter. Germany — Switzerland's largest trading partner — dragged exports down 8.4% in 2024, with US exports falling 14.2% in Q3 2025 and machine tool exports to the US cratering 43%.

These pressures are driving concrete behavioral changes. **83% of Swissmem companies are developing new markets; 62% are establishing new business areas.** Two-thirds of export-oriented SMEs adjusted their export strategy by July 2025. **31% of engineering firms are considering partial production shifts to the EU.** Companies are actively spending on market diversification, cybersecurity (67% plan budget increases per PwC), sustainability reporting (over 50% seek external consultants per ZHAW), and AI adoption (44% of Swiss SMEs have adopted AI per AWS). The top-quartile Swiss SMEs achieving **27% better currency shock resilience** through scenario automation demonstrate the competitive advantage of intelligence tools.

---

## Medtech and MEM: the two sectors Bramha should target first

The sector analysis across seven Swiss verticals yields a clear recommendation. **Medtech scores highest across all criteria, with MEM as the natural expansion market.** Together they represent approximately 2,500 addressable SMEs with acute, specific CI needs.

**Swiss medtech is the ideal MVP vertical.** The sector comprises **~1,400 companies, of which 95% are SMEs** (1,330+ addressable targets). Revenue reached CHF 23.4 billion in 2023, growing 2× faster than Swiss GDP. Approximately **90% of production is exported**, with the EU taking 50% (Germany #1) and the US as the largest single country. R&D investment runs at **12% of turnover** — indicating strong willingness to invest in tools that create competitive advantage. The sector generates ~1,200 patents per year, the highest per capita in Europe.

The CI needs are acute and specific. **Four out of five medtech companies hired additional staff** to handle EU Medical Device Regulation (MDR/IVDR) compliance — the sector's number one challenge. Companies increasingly consider getting FDA approval first due to more predictable processes, creating demand for comparative regulatory intelligence. The highly fragmented landscape with intense competition across segments drives competitor monitoring needs. TEPA specifically includes medical device tariff reductions, creating India market entry intelligence demand. Swiss Medtech, the industry association with 800+ members, provides a strong go-to-market channel.

**The MEM industry provides the natural second vertical.** Swissmem's 1,400+ member companies are **85% SMEs** (~1,190 targets). The sector generates CHF 87.4 billion in revenue and exports 80% of production — one-third of all Swiss goods exports. The current industrial recession (capacity utilization at 80.7% versus the 86.2% long-term average) creates urgency for market intelligence on alternative markets. India is one of the few growing export destinations (+8.1%), making TEPA-driven CI immediately relevant. Swissmem's Next Industries initiative provides a concrete partnership channel.

The sectors Bramha should avoid for MVP are clear from the data:

- **Fintech** — only 483 companies, sector saturating, VC funding collapsed to CHF 19 million, tech-native firms likely to DIY intelligence
- **Watchmaking** — highly concentrated (Rolex holds ~30% market share), dominated by a few groups, traditional culture slow to adopt SaaS
- **Food & beverage** — mostly domestic-focused, low export orientation, low digital maturity despite 3,681 companies
- **Pharma** — dominated by Roche and Novartis with extensive in-house CI; only 16.3% of pharma employees work in SMEs
- **Cleantech** — promising but too early-stage, fragmented across sectors, no consolidated addressable market

---

## Swissmem and Swiss Startup Association are the two highest-ROI channels

The Swiss association landscape offers concrete, actionable partnership models — not just networking. Three channels stand out for immediate execution.

**Swissmem's Next Industries partnership is the primary channel.** This not-for-profit platform, co-founded by Swissmem with asut and SwissTnet, connects industrial companies, solution providers, and universities for digital transformation. Solution providers can become official partners by contributing financial support and expertise. Benefits include membership in the community, free entries to the R&D Conference and Industry Forum, discounted exhibitor rates, and visibility as an official partner. The critical caveat: "Next Industries is not a sales platform and wants to preserve its neutral and trustworthy position." Partners must focus on industry competitiveness, not pure selling. Current partners include ControlTech Engineering, Bossard AG, Swisscom, and Eraneos. The Swissmem Industry Day attracts **1,000+ executives** and accepts exhibitors/sponsors. Estimated investment: **CHF 10,000–20,000/year** plus staff time.

**The Swiss Startup Association's "Offers for Startups" is the fastest path to endorsed vendor status.** This is the clearest vendor endorsement model found across all Swiss associations. Current partners include Stripe (50% on Atlas + CHF 10K credits), HubSpot (up to 30% off), Bexio (50% first year), and 1Password. The model is straightforward: offer a meaningful discount to SSA members and get listed as a recommended vendor. Cost is low — primarily the discount itself plus SSA membership. The IT & AI Desk curates recommended technology companies for startups, providing additional credibility.

**digitalswitzerland's Scaleup Bootcamps provide corporate matchmaking.** These one-day events match startups with Swiss corporates including AXA, Swisscom, UBS, Migros, and Zurich Insurance. Verticals cover Enterprise Tech & Cybersecurity, Smart Manufacturing, Life Sciences, and others — directly relevant for Bramha. The organization has **14,000+ newsletter subscribers** and 170+ member organizations. Membership costs are estimated at CHF 5,000–50,000 depending on organization size.

The cantonal chambers of commerce serve as regional penetration channels. The Zürcher Handelskammer (ZHK) represents **~1,000–1,200 companies** employing 200,000+ people and hosts regular events including cybersecurity seminars. Newsletter and event sponsoring runs **CHF 2,000–10,000**. The Chamber of Commerce Switzerland–Central Europe explicitly offers advertising packages reaching 2,000+ decision-makers.

Economiesuisse, SwissHoldings, and SGV/USAM are meta-organizations with no direct company programs — they should be bypassed in favor of their member associations. Scienceindustries (250 members, mostly large pharma/chemical) offers moderate potential only if Bramha develops pharma-specific features.

---

## The CI-plus-workshops bundle fills a proven market gap

The intelligence-to-action gap is a well-documented problem, and **no CI platform currently bundles implementation workshops with their SaaS tool** — making this a clear whitespace opportunity.

**The gap is real and costly.** Crayon's State of CI Report found that the average competitive team rates itself just **3.8 out of 10 in competitive selling**, costing companies **$2–$10 million annually** in winnable deals. Only 61% of businesses reported direct revenue impact from CI investments — meaning 39% saw no clear return. For the first time, CI practitioners are spending the greatest portion of their time on communication and activation rather than research, signaling industry-wide recognition that insight generation without implementation is wasteful.

**McKinsey's implementation model validates the bundle concept at enterprise scale.** McKinsey established a dedicated implementation practice in 2010, now employing **800+ implementation consultants across 18 global hubs**. They work "shoulder-to-shoulder" with clients from strategy through execution. BCG X has 3,000+ engineers and data scientists working alongside strategy consultants. Bain has a global OpenAI alliance for AI deployment. The entire MBB model is essentially "insight + activation" — proving the concept at the highest tier of the market.

**The gap for SMEs is that no one offers this at an accessible price point.** Major CI platforms — Klue ($30K–$50K/year stack), Crayon (most expensive, custom pricing), Kompyte (~$20K/year) — are pure SaaS with no workshop component. They offer customer success managers and onboarding, but not strategic implementation workshops. DIY tools (Google Alerts, Feedly, Visualping) cost under $5K but provide no activation support. The INSEAD-affiliated Xavier AI explicitly targets "McKinsey in a box" for the 99% of businesses that cannot afford traditional consulting — validating the democratization thesis.

**Recommended pricing for Swiss SMEs fills the gap between DIY and enterprise:**

- SaaS subscription: **CHF 500–1,500/month** (positioned between DIY tools and enterprise platforms)
- Quarterly implementation workshops: **CHF 2,000–5,000 per session**
- Annual bundle: **CHF 15,000–25,000** (tool + 4 workshops + ongoing support)
- This price point sits in the "missing middle" between $5K DIY approaches and $30K+ enterprise CI platforms

No Swiss company was found explicitly combining CI SaaS tools with implementation workshops. Swiss examples of adjacent models include gopf (AI/data workshops), Glaswerk Digital's "GrowBetter" methodology (consulting + digital marketing), and Noser Engineering (workshops alongside digital transformation services). The Swiss market's premium pricing tolerance and trust-based buying culture make the workshop component a competitive moat, not just a revenue line.

---

## Conversational AI for reports is a differentiator, not a novelty

The evidence strongly supports building a conversational interface for Bramha's CI reports, with important caveats about implementation quality.

**Every major BI vendor is investing in conversational analytics.** Microsoft (Power BI Copilot), Google (Looker Conversational Analytics), Salesforce (Tableau Next), and ThoughtSpot (Spotter) all treat natural language query as a core feature, not an experiment. The global conversational AI market reached **$11.58 billion in 2024** and is projected to hit **$41.39 billion by 2030** at a 23.7% CAGR. SMEs are the fastest-growing adopter segment at **25.1% CAGR**. Gartner's 2025 Hype Cycle places natural language query at the "Peak of Inflated Expectations" with a **transformational benefit rating** and mainstream adoption expected within two years.

**In competitive intelligence specifically, Klue proves the model works.** Klue's "Ask Klue" GenAI co-pilot answers competitive questions directly in Slack, Salesforce, or the Klue platform. Their Compete Agent proactively monitors deals, detects competitors in sales calls via Gong integration, and pushes personalized deal tips. One customer testimonial claims a **28% increase in win rates** and two days per week saved. Klue's AI Interviewer conducts asynchronous voice/text interviews to capture deal intelligence. With **250,000+ users**, this is validated at scale. Crayon offers a lighter "Crayon Answers" feature for competitive Q&A.

**For SME executives specifically, conversational CI solves a real problem.** SME executives don't have CI teams. They cannot read 50-page reports. The ability to ask "What are my competitor's latest pricing changes?" and get an instant, sourced answer is genuinely valuable — not a demo trick. ThoughtSpot reported one customer going from **20% of the business using analytics to 80%** after deploying their conversational interface. The adoption trajectory is clear.

**The critical caveat is accuracy.** AtScale research found that LLMs achieve **less than 20% accuracy** on complex business queries when working directly with raw data without semantic context. Competitive intelligence, however, is an ideal narrow domain for conversational AI — limited scope, well-defined entities (competitors, products, prices, regulations), and curated data sets. Building a strong semantic layer and using retrieval-augmented generation over curated CI data eliminates most hallucination concerns. The technology works best when the domain is narrow, data is properly governed, and human oversight exists — all achievable for a focused CI platform.

---

## Three adjacent products with proven demand and willingness to pay

Beyond core competitive intelligence, three product extensions have the strongest evidence of demand from Swiss SMEs.

**Regulatory compliance monitoring is the most urgent adjacent opportunity.** Multiple EU regulations are simultaneously hitting Swiss exporters with no affordable monitoring tool available. The EU AI Act applies extraterritorially to Swiss companies selling to the EU, with fines up to **€35 million or 7% of global turnover**. CBAM entered its regular phase on January 1, 2026, requiring Swiss exporters of steel, aluminum, cement, and fertilizers to manage carbon border adjustment certificates. Switzerland is proposing to expand sustainability reporting requirements from ~300 to ~3,500 companies by lowering the employee threshold from 500 to 250. Existing enterprise GRC platforms (MetricStream, Wolters Kluwer, AuditBoard) cost **$50,000–$500,000+/year** and target large financial institutions. PwC, EY, and KPMG run AI Act readiness assessments as expensive consulting engagements. **No affordable, Swiss-focused regulatory monitoring tool exists** that tracks AI Act, CSRD, CBAM, and FADP compliance in one dashboard. The monitoring-and-alerting architecture of a CI platform maps naturally to this use case.

**Export market assessment reports extend CI into market entry decisions.** S-GE provides excellent but human-driven, high-touch consulting that doesn't scale for continuous monitoring. Their GoGlobal Cockpit is free but lacks competitive intelligence, real-time updates, and actionable recommendations. With TEPA creating new India market entry demand and 83% of Swissmem companies actively developing new markets, the need for automated, continuously updated export market intelligence is real. A self-service dashboard combining trade data, competitor analysis, regulatory conditions, and market entry scoring would fill the gap between S-GE's basic tools and Big 4 consulting.

**Grant and funding opportunity monitoring addresses a fragmented landscape.** Innosuisse received **373 applications** for the Swiss Accelerator program in 2023 alone (approving 33 for CHF 60.4 million). Switzerland regained full Horizon Europe participation in 2025, opening EUR 95.5 billion in EU program funding. But the grant landscape is fragmented across Innosuisse, SERI, SNSF, cantonal programs, and EU programs with no single monitoring dashboard. **53% of SMEs receiving Innosuisse innovation cheques were collaborating with research for the first time** — suggesting many SMEs are unaware of available funding. A monitoring and alerting service that tracks relevant deadlines, eligibility changes, and match-scores opportunities to company profiles would be a high-value differentiator.

Supply chain intelligence (alternative supplier discovery, risk monitoring) is a medium-priority feature rather than a standalone product — better integrated as supplier risk alerts within the CI platform. Talent market intelligence has real demand given Switzerland's 117,000+ IT specialist shortage, but it's an HR function distant from core CI users — a lightweight competitor job-posting monitor suffices. M&A target screening serves an active market (~179–200 deals/year per Deloitte) but the addressable audience is narrow. IP/patent monitoring tools are well-served by established players (PatSnap at $10K–$50K/year, Orbit Intelligence, free tools like Google Patents) and should remain a future premium add-on.

---

## How the India-Switzerland corridor creates a unique positioning

The founder's Indian origin is not just biographical — it is a strategic asset that maps to a genuine market need. **TEPA positions India as the primary "China+1" destination for Swiss companies**, and this creates a differentiated product opportunity that no Swiss-based CI competitor currently addresses.

The University of St. Gallen's 2025 Swiss Business in China Survey reveals the tension: **60% of Swiss companies describe China's near-term environment as "very challenging"** even as 43% expect higher revenues. Profit expectations tell the real story — only 29% expect higher profits (net +2%), indicating severe margin compression. Nearly 50% of global supply chain executives are looking to reduce Chinese sourcing dependency to no more than 20% of direct manufacturing within the decade. PwC Switzerland explicitly notes that "India offers many companies the opportunity to pursue a 'China+1 strategy' and therefore reduce their dependence on China."

TEPA amplifies this with structural advantages. Swiss companies get preferential market access that EU competitors lack. The $100 billion EFTA investment commitment (with India able to suspend tariff concessions if targets aren't met) creates institutional momentum. Financial services see banking FDI limits raised from 51% to 74%. Machinery personnel can reside in India up to 90 days for installation and maintenance. IP protections and geographical indication protections are strengthened.

Bramha can position the India market intelligence module as a TEPA-activation product: helping Swiss SMEs understand Indian competitors, navigate BIS certification requirements, identify distribution partners, compare India versus China for sourcing decisions, and monitor the $100 billion investment pipeline for partnership opportunities. The India-EFTA Desk, operational since February 2025, provides facilitation but not intelligence — creating a clear complementary role for Bramha.

---

## Conclusion: the concrete decisions

The evidence points to five decisive product and GTM choices:

**Target medtech first, MEM second.** Medtech's 1,330+ SMEs, 12% R&D spending, acute regulatory CI needs (MDR/IVDR), and 90% export orientation make it the highest-probability MVP vertical. MEM's 1,190+ SMEs, extreme export pressure, and overlapping supply chains provide the natural expansion. Together, ~2,500 SMEs with specific, demonstrable CI needs.

**Bundle workshops with the platform at CHF 15,000–25,000/year.** No CI vendor does this. The intelligence-to-action gap costs companies $2–$10 million in winnable deals annually. The workshop model mirrors democratized McKinsey at an SME-accessible price point and creates a trust-based selling relationship that pure SaaS cannot match in the Swiss market.

**Build conversational CI as a core differentiator, not a feature.** The trajectory from Gartner, adoption data (SME segment at 25.1% CAGR), and Klue's validation (28% win rate increase) confirm this is substantive. For SME executives without CI teams, the ability to query intelligence conversationally is transformational, not incremental.

**Launch regulatory compliance monitoring as the first adjacent product.** CBAM is live since January 2026. CSRD is expanding. AI Act fines reach 7% of global turnover. No affordable Swiss-focused tool exists. The monitoring architecture is identical to CI. This product practically sells itself alongside competitive intelligence.

**Enter through Swissmem's Next Industries and Swiss Medtech simultaneously.** Budget CHF 10,000–20,000/year for Swissmem partnership, get listed on the Swiss Startup Association's endorsed vendor program immediately (near-zero cost), and apply for digitalswitzerland's Scaleup Bootcamp for corporate matchmaking. The TEPA angle provides a time-sensitive hook — Swiss companies are evaluating India market entry now, before the EU negotiates its own agreement.
